lesson.name: Lesson 8.8 Teacher Guide: Rewriting Quadratic Expressions in Factored Form, Part 3

page.title: 8.8.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

So far, the quadratic expressions that students have transformed from standard form to factored form have at least a squared term and a linear term. In this lesson, students encounter quadratic expressions without a linear term and consider how to write them in factored form.

Students begin by studying numerical examples and noticing that expressions such as \((20 + 1)(20 − 1)\) and \(20^2− 1^2\) (which is a difference of two squares) are equivalent. Students are able to generalize the equivalence of these two forms as \((x + m)(x − m) = x^2− m^2\). Then, they rewrite these expressions from one form to the other.

Along the way, they encounter a variety of quadratic expressions that can be seen as differences of two squares, including those in which the squared term has a coefficient other than 1, and expressions that involve fractions.

Students also consider why a difference of two squares (such as \(x^2− 25\)) can be written in factored form, but a sum of two squares (such as \(x^2 + 25\)) cannot be, even though both are quadratic expressions with no linear term.

Remind students that when they want to enter a number with an exponent, they should use the ^ symbol. It will look like "\(x^2\)" when they want to enter \(x^2\). To make the ^ symbol, push shift and the numeral 6 at the same time.

After this lesson, students will have the tools they need to solve factorable quadratic equations given in standard form by first rewriting them in factored form. That work begins in the next lesson.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Explain that multiplying binomials that are a sum and a difference, \((x + m)(x − m)\), results in a quadratic with no linear term and explain (orally) why this is the case.
  • Write equivalent expressions in factored form when given quadratic expressions that are the difference of squares.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Explain why multiplying binomials that are a sum and a difference, \((x + m)(x − m)\), results in a quadratic expression with no linear term.
  • Rewrite a quadratic expression of the form \(x^2− c\) into its factored form.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula.

Foundational: Lesson provides foundational content necessary for students to be able to perform this TEKS in later lessons.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 8.8.1: Evaluating Expressions Using Mental Math
  • 8.8.2: Recognizing the Expanded Product of the Difference of Two Squares
    • 8.8.2: Self Check
    • 8.8.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.8.3: Factoring Quadratic Equations Without a Linear Term
    • 8.8.3: Self Check
    • 8.8.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.8.4: Determining if an Expression Can Be Rewritten in Factored Form

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 8.8.5: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Paper and pencil

Required Preparation

  • None

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson.
  • Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in "math talk" and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards.

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:


Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • quadratic expression
  • factored form (of a quadratic expression)
  • standard form (of a quadratic expression)
  • variable
  • difference of squares
  • root
  • linear term
  • none

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their curiosity.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • Ask, Don’t Tell
  • How to Benefit from Boredom

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Curiosity from Character Lab.

page.title: 8.8.1: Evaluating Expressions Using Mental Math
page.contents:
Warm Up (10 minutes)

This warm up activity prompts students to recall strategies for multiplying mentally.

Each expression can be evaluated in different ways. For example, \(19 \cdot 21\) can be viewed as \(19 \cdot (20 + 1)\), as \(21 \cdot (20 − 1)\), or as \((20 − 1) \cdot (20 + 1)\), among other ways. Reasoning flexibly about the structure of numerical expressions encourages students to do the same when rewriting quadratic expressions in this lesson and beyond.

Launch

Display one problem at a time. Give students quiet think time for each problem and ask them to give a signal when they have an answer and a strategy. Keep all problems displayed throughout the talk. Follow with a whole-class discussion.

Student Activity

Finding a product mentally can be done by changing the way you look at a multiplication problem.

For example, \(9 \cdot 39\) can be thought of as \(9 \cdot (40 − 1)\). For some people, this might be easier to calculate mentally since you can imagine the solution as \(360 − 9\), or 351. This method leverages the distributive property of multiplication over addition.

For the following questions, find each product mentally. Then, explain how you changed the way you looked at each multiplication problem to use the distributive property.

  1. \(9 \cdot 11\)

Answer: 99
For example, \(9 \cdot 11\) can be thought of as \(9 \cdot (10 + 1)\). This simplifies to \(90 + 9\), or 99.

  1. \(19 \cdot 21\)

Answer: 399
For example, \(19 \cdot 21\) can be thought of as \(19 \cdot (20 + 1)\). This simplifies to \(380 + 19\), or 399.

  1. \(99 \cdot 101\)

Answer: 9999
For example, \(99 \cdot 101\) can be thought of as \(99 \cdot (100 + 1)\). This simplifies to \(9900 + 99\), or 9999.

  1. \(109 \cdot 101\)

Answer: 11,009
For example, \(109 \cdot 101\) can be thought of as \(109 \cdot (100 + 1)\). This simplifies to \(10,900 + 109\), or 11,009.

Activity Synthesis

Ask students to share their strategies for each problem. Record and display their responses for all to see. To involve more students in the conversation, consider asking:

  • "Who can restate _______’s reasoning in a different way?"
  • "Did anyone have the same strategy but would explain it differently?"
  • "Did anyone solve the problem in a different way?"
  • "Does anyone want to add on to _______’s strategy?"
  • "Do you agree or disagree? Why?"

page.title: 8.8.2: Recognizing the Expanded Product of the Difference of Two Squares
page.contents:
Activity (15 minutes)

In this activity, students multiply expressions of the form \((x + m)\) and \((x - m)\). They discover that the expanded product of such factors can be expressed as a difference of two square numbers: \(x^2- m^2\). Students use diagrams and the distributive property to make sense of their observations.

In the last question, they have an opportunity to notice that an expression in the form \((x + m)^2\) is not equivalent to \(x^2+ m^2\), to discourage overgeneralizing. Later in the lesson, they will transform quadratic expressions in standard form into factored form and vice versa.

To answer the first two questions, some students may simply evaluate the expressions rather than reasoning about their structure. For example, to see if \((10 + 3)(10 - 3)\) is equivalent to \(10^2- 3^2\), they may calculate \(13 \cdot 7\) and \(100 - 9\) and see that both are 91. Ask students to see if they could show that this is not a coincidence. Could they show, for example, that \((50 + 4)(50 - 4)\) would also be equivalent to \(50^2-4^2\)?

As students work, look for those who expand the factored expression using the distributive property and leave the partial products unevaluated to show the equivalence of the two expressions.

Launch

Provide access to calculators, in case requested.

Student Activity

  1. Clare claims that \((10 + 3)(10 - 3)\) is equivalent to \(10^2-3^2\) and \((20 + 1)(20 - 1)\) is equivalent to \(20^2-1^2\). Do you agree? Show your reasoning.

Answer: Agree.

\((10+3)(10-3)\)
\(\begin{array}{rcl}&&{=\left(10+3\right)\left(10+(-3)\right)\\=10^2+10\left(-3\right)+3\left(10\right)+3\left(-3\right)\\=10^2-30+30-3^2\\=10^2-3^2}\\&&\end{array}\)

\((20 + 1)(20 - 1)\)
\(\begin{array}{rcl}&&{=\left(20 + (-1)\right)\left(20 -1\right)\\= 20^2+ 20\left(-1\right) + 20\left(1\right) + 1\left(-1\right) \\= 20^2- 12}\\&&\end{array}\)

  1. You can use your observations from the first question to mentally solve an expression such as \(105 \cdot 95\).
  1. First, think about the problem differently. Evaluate \((100 + 5)(100 - 5)\) using the distributive property, or FOIL. Show your reasoning.

Answer: \((100 + 5)(100 - 5) = 100^2- 5^2= 10,000 - 25 = 9975\)

  1. Check your answer by computing \(105 \cdot 95\).

Answer: \(105 \cdot 95 = 9975\)

  1. Is \((x + 4)(x - 4)\) equivalent to \(x^2-4^2\)?
  1. First, support your thinking using a diagram.
 

\(x\)

4

\(x\)

    

-4

    

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: Yes.

 

\(x\)

4

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(4x\)

-4

\(-4x\)

\(-4(4)\)

  1. Now, support your thinking using the distributive property, or FOIL.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \((x + 4)(x - 4)= x^2+ 4x - 4x - 4(4) = x^2- 4^2\)

  1. Is \((x + 4)^2\) equivalent to \(x^2+4^2\)? Support your answer, either with or without a diagram.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: No.
With a diagram:

 

\(x\)

4

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(4x\)

4

\(4x\)

\(4(4)\)

With FOIL:
\((x + 4)^2= (x + 4)(x + 4) = x^2+4x +4x +4(4) = x^2+8x +16\)
\(x^2+ 4^2 = x^2+ 16\)

Student-Facing Extension

Extending Your Thinking
  1. Explain how your work in the previous questions can help you mentally evaluate \(22 \cdot 18\).

Answer: \(22 \cdot 18\) can be written as \((20 + 2)(20 - 2)\), which is equivalent to \(202 - 22\), which is \(400 - 4\), or 396.

  1. Explain how your work in the previous questions can help you mentally evaluate \(45 \cdot 35\).

Answer: \(45 \cdot 35\) can be written as \((40 + 5)(40 - 5)\), which is equivalent to \(40^2-5^2\), which is \(1600 - 25\), or 1575.

Here is a shortcut that can be used to mentally square any two-digit number. Let's take \(83^2\), for example.

  • 83 is \(80 + 3\).
  • Compute \(80^2\) and \(3^2\), which gives 6400 and 9. Add these values to get 6409.
  • Compute \(80 \cdot 3\), which is 240. Double it to get 480.
  • Add 6409 and 480 to get 6889.

Try using this method to find the squares of some other two-digit numbers. (With some practice, it is possible to get really fast at this!)

  1. Explain why this method works.

Answer: Any two-digit number can be written as \(a + b\), where \(a\) is 10 times the first digit and \(b\) is the second digit. We are interested in squaring \(a + b\):

\((a + b)^2=(a + b)(a + b)\)

\(= a^2+ab +ab +b^2\) by the distributive property

\(= a^2+ 2ab +b^2\) by combining like terms

\(= a^2+b^2+2ab\) because addition is commutative


We get the \(a^2 + b^2\) from squaring \(a\) and \(b\) and adding them, and the \(2ab\) from multiplying the two values and doubling them.

Anticipated Misconceptions

Some students may struggle to generalize the pattern after just a few examples. Before starting the activity synthesis, provide additional factored expressions for students to expand, for instance: \((x + 3)(x - 3)\), \((2x + 1)(2x - 1)\), \((4x + 5)(4x - 5)\), and \((6 - x)(6 + x)\).

Activity Synthesis

To help students generalize their observations, display the expression \((x + m)(x - m)\) and a blank diagram that can be used to visualize the expansion of the factors. Ask students what expressions go in each rectangle.

 

\(x\)

\(m\)

\(x\)

    

\(-m\)

    

Illustrate that when the terms in each factor are multiplied out, the resulting expression has two squares, one with a positive coefficient and the other with a negative coefficient (\(x^2\) and \(m^2\)) and two linear terms that are opposites (\(mx\) and \(-mx\)). Because the sum of \(mx\) and \(-mx\) is 0, what remains is the difference of \(x^2\) and \(m^2\), or \(x^2 - m^2\). There is now no linear term.

Emphasize that knowing this allows us to rewrite into factored form any quadratic expression that has no linear term and that is a difference of a squared variable and a squared constant. For example, we can write \(x^2-9\) as \((x + 3)(x - 3)\) because we know that when the latter is expanded, the result is \(x^2-9\).

Use the last question to point out the importance of paying attention to the structure of these expressions (the subtraction in the first expression, the presence of both addition and subtraction in the second). For example, we can't use any patterns observed in this activity to rewrite \(x^2+9\) in factored form.

8.8.2: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Which of the following is equivalent to \(9^2 - 6^2\)?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\((9 - 6)^2\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This expression is \((9 - 6)^2= 3^2= 9\). The original expression is \(9^2- 6^2= 81 - 36 = 45\). The answer is \((9 + 6)(9 - 6)\).

\((9 - 6)(9 - 6)\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This expression is \((9 - 6)(9 - 6) = (3)(3) = 9\). The original expression is \(9^2 - 6^2= 81 - 36 = 45\). The answer is \((9 + 6)(9 - 6)\).

\((9 + 6)(9 + 6)\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This expression is \((9 + 6)(9 + 6) = (15)(15) = 225\). The original expression is \(9^2- 6^2= 81 - 36 = 45\). The answer is \((9 + 6)(9 - 6)\).

\((9 + 6)(9 - 6)\)

That's correct! Check yourself: Multiply the expression to check. \((9 + 6)(9 - 6) = (15)(3) = 45\). The original expression is equivalent, \(9^2- 6^2= 81 - 36 = 45\). The answer is correct.

8.8.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Recognizing the Expanded Product of the Difference of Two Squares

Example 1

Let's look at the expression \((12 + 5)(12 - 5)\). We want to determine if it is equivalent to \(12^2-5^2\).

We can use the distributive property of multiplication over addition, or FOIL process, to multiply.

\((12 + 5)(12 - 5)\)

\(\begin{array}{rcl} &=&12^2-12\left(5\right)+5\left(12\right)-5^2\\&&\\&=&12^2-60+60-5^2\\&&\\&=&12^2-5^2\\&&\end{array}\)
So, \((12 + 5)(12 - 5)\) is equivalent to \(12^2-5^2\).

Example 2

Let's look at a different example using a variable.

\((x + 7)(x - 7)\)

Is this equivalent to \(x^2-7^2\)?

\((x + 7)(x - 7)\)

\(\begin{array}{rcl} &=&x^2-7x+7x-7^2\\&&\\&=&x^2-7^2=x^2-49\\&&\end{array}\)
This can also be shown using a diagram.

 

\(x\)

-7

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(-7x\)

7

\(7x\)

\(-7(7)\)

You have studied this process earlier when you learned the difference of squares.

In this lesson, we will reverse this process to rewrite the standard form of a quadratic expression into its factored form.

It is important to remember the linear term, or middle term of a quadratic trinomial, equals zero only holds true for the difference of squares. It does not work for an expression such as \(x^2+25\). (In fact, there is no way to multiply two binomials that would result in this expression.)

Example 3

Is \((x + 5)^2\) equivalent to \(x^2+25\)?

Let's find the equivalent expression for \((x + 5)^2\) or \((x + 5)(x + 5)\).

\(\begin{array}{rcl}\left(x+5\right)^2&=&\left(x+5\right)\left(x+5\right)\\&&\\&=&x^2+5x+5x+25\\&&\\&=&x^2+10x+25\\&&\end{array}\)
Since \(x^2+ 10x + 25\) is not equivalent to \(x^2+25\), these expressions are not the same.

Try It: Recognizing the Expanded Product of the Difference of Two Squares

  1. Is the expression \((8 - 7)(8 + 7)\) equivalent to the expression \(8^2-7^2\)? Show your reasoning using the distributive property, or FOIL.
  1. Is \((x + 4)(x + 4)\) equivalent to \(x^2+ 4^2\)? Support your answer with a diagram.

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to recognize the expanded product of the difference of two squares:

  1. Yes. Here is how to use the difference of squares to show equivalency between the expressions:

\((8 - 7)(8 + 7) = 8^2+ 56 - 56 - 7^2= 8^2 - 7^2\)

  1. No. The expressions are not equivalent.
 

\(x\)

4

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(4x\)

4

\(4x\)

\(4(4)\)

\((x + 4)(x + 4) = x^2 + 8x + 4^2 = x^2 + 8x + 16\)

It is not equivalent to \(x^2 + 4^2 = x^2 + 16\).

page.title: 8.8.3: Factoring Quadratic Equations Without a Linear Term
page.contents:
Activity (10 minutes)

In this activity, students use the insights from the previous activity to write equivalent quadratic expressions in standard form and factored form. They see that when a quadratic expression in standard form is a difference of two squares (a squared variable, \(x^2\), and a squared constant, \(m^2\)) and has no linear term, the factored form is \((x + m)(x − m)\). Even if the constant term is not a perfect square, we can still find the factored form, but the numbers in the factors would not be rational numbers. For example, the expression \(x^2−12\) can be written as \((x + \sqrt{12})(x − \sqrt{12})\) because \(\sqrt{12} \cdot -\sqrt{12} = -12\). If we expand \((x + \sqrt{12})(x − \sqrt{12})\), there will be no linear term because \(\sqrt{12}x + (-\sqrt{12}x) = 0\).

Students also notice that when a quadratic expression is a sum (instead of a difference) of a squared variable and a squared constant, it cannot be written in factored form.

Launch

Consider arranging students in groups of two and asking them to think quietly about the problems before discussing their responses with their partner.

Ask students to write as many equivalent expressions as time permits while aiming to complete at least the first six rows and the last row of the table.

Student Activity

In questions 1 and 2, each row of the table contains a pair of equivalent expressions.

  1. Convert the factored form expression to the standard form.

If you get stuck, consider drawing a diagram.

Factored form

Standard form

\((x − 10)(x + 10)\)

  

\((2x + 1)(2x − 1)\)

  

\((4 − x)(4 + x)\)

  

\((c + \frac{2}{5})(c − \frac{2}{5})\)

  

\((x + 5)(x + 5)\)

  

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answers:

Factored form

Standard form

\((x − 10)(x + 10)\)

\(x^2 − 100\)

\((2x + 1)(2x − 1)\)

\(4x^2− 1\)

\((4 − x)(4 + x)\)

\(16 − x^2\)

\((c + \frac {2}{5})(c − \frac {2}{5})\)

\(c^2 − \frac {4}{25}\)

\((x + 5)(x + 5)\)

\(x^2+ 10x + 25\)

  1. Convert the standard form expression to the factored form.

If you get stuck, consider drawing a diagram. (HINT: One of the expressions does not convert.)

Factored form

Standard form
 

\(x^2 − 81\)
 

\(49 − y^2\)
 

\(9z^2 − 16\)
 

\(25t^2− 81\)
 

\(\frac {49}{16} − d^2\)
 

\(x^2− 6\)
 

\(x^2 + 100\)

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answers:

Factored form

Standard form

\((x − 9)(x + 9)\)

\(x^2 − 81\)

\((7 − y)(7 + y)\)

\(49 − y^2\)

\((3z + 4)(3z − 4)\)

\(9z^2 − 16\)

\((5t + 9)(5t − 9)\)

\(25t^2− 81\)

\((\frac {7}{4} − d)(\frac {7}{4} + d)\)

\(\frac {49}{16} − d^2\)

\((x − \sqrt{6})(x + \sqrt{6})\)

\(x^2− 6\)

prime

\(x^2 + 100\)

Video: Factoring Quadratic Equations Without a Linear Term

Watch the following video to learn more about factoring a quadratic equation that is written in standard form and has no linear term.



Anticipated Misconceptions

Some students may struggle to see the numbers in the expressions in standard form as perfect squares. Prompt them to create a list or table of square numbers (\(1^2=1\), \(2^2=4\), \(3^2=9\), and so on) to have as a handy reference. Others may benefit by rewriting both terms as squares before writing the factored form. Demonstrate how to rewrite \(49x^2- 81\) as \((7x)^2-(9)^2\) and \(\frac {1}{4}x^2-25\) as \((\frac {1}{2}x)^2- (5)^2\).

Activity Synthesis

Consider displaying the incomplete table for all to see and asking students to record their responses. Give the class time to examine the responses and to bring up any disagreements or questions. Discuss with students:

  • "How can we check if the expression in factored form is indeed equivalent to the given expression in standard form?" (We can expand the factored expression by applying the distributive property and see if it gives the expression in standard form.)
  • "Some of the expressions show a squared variable subtracted from a number, instead of the other way around. Can we still write an equivalent expression in factored form?" (Yes. As long as the expression in standard form can be written as a difference of two squares, it can be written in factored form.)
  • "What if the number is not a perfect square, for example, \(x^2−5\)?" (We can still write it in factored form, by thinking about what number can be squared to get 5. Both \(\sqrt{5}\) and \(-\sqrt{5}\) can be squared to get 5. Regardless of which number we use, the factored form is \((x + \sqrt{5})(x − \sqrt{5})\)).
  • "Why can \(x^2−100\) be written in factored form but \(x^2+100\) cannot?" (One possible approach is to rewrite the former as \(x^2+0x −100\). We learned previously that, to write this expression in factored form, we would need to look for two numbers whose product is –100 and whose sum is 0. The numbers 10 and –10 meet this requirement. For \(x^2+0x +100\), however, we need two numbers whose product is 100 and whose sum is 0. No such numbers exist. To have a sum of 0, one number has to be positive and the other negative, so their product can’t be positive 100.)

8.8.3 Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Find the factored form of the expression \(16p^2 − 49\).

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\((4p + 7)(4p − 7)\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply the factored form to check. \((4p + 7)(4p − 7) = 16p^2−28p +28p −49 = 16p^2− 49\). The answer is correct.

\((4p + 7)(4p + 7)\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This expression multiplies to be \((4p + 7)(4p + 7) = 16p^2+56p +49\). Look for the binomials that lead to the middle terms canceling each other out because they are opposites. The answer is \((4p + 7)(4p − 7)\).

\((4p − 7)(4p − 7)\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This expression multiplies to be \((4p − 7)(4p − 7) = 16p^2−56p +49\). Look for the binomials that lead to the middle terms canceling each other out because they are opposites. The answer is \((4p + 7)(4p − 7)\).

\(p(16p − 49)\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This expression multiplies to be \(p(16p − 49) = 16p^2− 49p\). The answer is \((4p + 7)(4p − 7)\).

8.8.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Factoring Quadratic Equations Without a Linear Term

We can use what we have learned in the previous lesson to write quadratic equations of a special form into factored form.

Particularly, we can rewrite:

\(x^2− c^2\) into \((x + c)(x − c)\).

Let’s look at an example.

Example 1

Write \(v^2−36\) in factored form.

We know that the form we are looking for is \((v\;−\) __ \()(v \;+\) __ \()\).

Since we know the square root of \(v^2\) is \(v\) and the square root of 36 is 6, the factored form is \((v − 6)(v + 6)\).

We can multiply to check our work.

\((v − 6)(v + 6)\)
\(\begin{array}{rcl}&&{=v^2+6v-6v-36\\=v^2-36\; {\style{color:red}\checkmark}}\\&&\end{array}\)

The process is similar when there is a coefficient on the squared term.

\(a^2x^2−c^2\;\;\;\;\) factors into \(\;\;\;\;(ax + c)(ax − c)\)

Let’s look at another example to understand the process.

Example 2

Write \(16m^2− 81\) in factored form.

The form we are looking for now is ( __ − __ )( __ + __ ).

Taking the square root of the first term gives us \(4m\).

So, we have \((4m \;−\) __ \()(4m \;+\) __ \()\).

Now, we are in the same place as in the previous example. The square root of 81 is 9.

So, the factored form is \((4m − 9 )(4m + 9)\).

Again, we can multiply to check.

\((4m − 9)(4m + 9)\)
\(\begin{array}{rcl}&&{= 4m^2 + 36m − 36m − 81\\= 4m^2 − 81\; {\style{color:red}\checkmark}}\\&&\end{array}\)

Example 3

As we see in the activity, where the variable is located is not important as long as the quadratic binomial is still the difference of two squares.

Write \(64 − 9b^2\) in factored form.

We use the same concept to find the factored form.

\(64 − 9b^2= (8 − 3b)(8 + 3b)\)

We can multiply to check.

\((8 − 3b)(8 + 3b)\)
\(\begin{array}{rcl}&&{= 64 + 24b − 24b − 9b^2\\= 64 − 9b^2\; {\style{color:red}\checkmark}}\\&&\end{array}\)

Remember that any expression of the form \(x^2 + c\) or \(ax^2+ c\) does not have a factored form!

  • For \(x^2+ c\), the \(c\) is not squared, and the terms are not being subtracted.
  • For \(ax^2+ c\), neither the \(a\) nor the \(c\) is a perfect square, and the terms are not being subtracted.

Try It: Factoring Quadratic Equations Without a Linear Term

  1. Write \(x^2− 4\) in factored form.
  1. Write \(100x^2− 121\) in factored form.

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to write the expressions in factored form.

  1. \((x − 2)(x + 2)\)
  1. \((10x − 11)(10x + 11)\)

page.title: 8.8.4: Determining if an Expression Can Be Rewritten in Factored Form
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Student Activity

Write each expression in factored form. If it is not possible, write “not possible.”

  1. \(a^2− 36\)

Answer: \((a + 6)(a − 6)\)

  1. \(49 − 25b^2\)

Answer: \((7 + 5b)(7 − 5b)\)

  1. \(c^2+ 9\)

Answer: Not possible because this is the sum of two squares.

  1. \(\frac {100}{81}-16d^2\)

Answer: \((\frac {10}{9} + 4d)(\frac {10}{9} − 4d)\)

page.title: 8.8.5: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.
  1. Which of the following is equivalent to \(10^2−12^2\)?
  • \((10 + 12)(10 + 12)\)
  • \((10 − 12)(10 − 12)\)
  • \((10 −12)^2\)
  • \((10 + 12)(10 − 12)\)

Answer: \((10 + 12)(10 − 12)\)

For questions 2–10, select the expression in factored form.

  1. \(c^2 − 25\)
  • \(c(c − 25)\)
  • \((c − 5)(c − 5)\)
  • \((c − 5)(c + 5)\)
  • \((c + 5)(c + 5)\)

Answer: \((c − 5)(c + 5)\)

  1. \(9w^2 − 121\)
  • \((3w − 11)(3w + 11)\)
  • \((3w + 11)(3w + 11)\)
  • \(w(9w − 121)\)
  • \((3w − 11)(3w − 11)\)

Answer: \((3w − 11)(3w + 11)\)

  1. \(h^2− 121\)
  • \((h − 11)^2\)
  • \((h − 11)(h + 11)\)
  • \((h − 11)(h − 11)\)
  • \((h + 11)(h + 11)\)

Answer: \((h − 11)(h + 11)\)

  1. \(64 − d^2\)
  • \((8 − d)(8 − d)\)
  • \((8 − d)(8 + d)\)
  • \((8 + d)(8 + d)\)
  • Not possible

Answer: \((8 − d)(8 + d)\)

  1. \(4b^2 − 25\)
  • \((2b − 5)(2b + 5)\)
  • \((2b − 5)(2b − 5)\)
  • \(b(4b − 25)\)
  • \((2b + 5)(2b + 5)\)

Answer: \((2b − 5)(2b + 5)\)

  1. \(49 − 81z^2\)
  • \((7 + 9z)(7 + 9z)\)
  • \((7 − 9z)(7 − 9z)\)
  • \(z(49 − 81z)\)
  • \((7 − 9z)(7 + 9z)\)

Answer: \((7 − 9z)(7 + 9z)\)

  1. \(100y^2−4\)
  • \((10y + 2)(10y + 2)\)
  • \((10y − 2)(10y + 2)\)
  • \((10y − 2)(10y − 2)\)
  • Not possible

Answer: \((10y − 2)(10y + 2)\)

  1. \(x^2+9\)
  • \((x − 3)(x − 3)\)
  • \((x − 3)(x + 3)\)
  • \((x + 3)(x + 3)\)
  • Not possible

Answer: Not possible

  1. \(144 − 16g^2\)
  • \((12 − 4g)(12 + 4g)\)
  • \((12 + 4g)(12 + 4g)\)
  • \((12 − 4g)(12 − 4g)\)
  • Not possible

Answer: \((12 − 4g)(12 + 4g)\)

page.title: 8.8.6: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
To help students consolidate and articulate their understanding of the relationship between \((x + m)(x − m)\) and \(x^2− m^2\), ask them to reflect, in writing or by talking to a partner, on questions such as:

  • “The expression \((x + 4)(x − 4)\) has a sum and a difference, and so does \((x + 8)(x − 2)\). When expanded into standard form, why does one have a linear term but the other does not?” (Multiplying out \((x + 4)(x − 4)\) gives two linear terms that are opposites, \(4x\) and \(-4x\), which add up to 0, so the linear term disappears. Multiplying out \((x + 8)(x − 2)\) also gives two linear terms, \(8x\) and \(-2x\). Because they are not opposites, their sum is not 0, so the linear term remains.)
  • “Can \(\frac {1}{4} − 100m^2\) be seen as a difference of two squares? Can it be written in factored form? If so, what would it be?” (Yes. \(\frac {1}{2}\) squared is \(\frac {1}{4}\), and \((10m)^2\) is \(100m^2\). The factored form is \((\frac {1}{2} + 10m)(\frac {1}{2} − 10m)\)).
  • “Think of another example of a quadratic expression in factored form that, when rewritten in standard form, is a difference of two squares and does not have a linear term. What is the expression in standard form?” (Answers may vary. For example, factored form: \((2x+9)(2x-9)\); standard form: \(4x^2 - 81\).)
